choices.C: Convert the service account mailboxes into shared mailboxes.
choices.D: Convert the service account mailboxes into mail-enabled users.
choices.B: Replace the service account mailboxes with a mail-enabled group.
choices.A: Replace the service account mailboxes with a single user mailbox that contains journal rules.

questions.question_text:
You have 1,000 user accounts that are each licensed for Microsoft 365. Each user account has a Microsoft Exchange Online mailbox.
Ten of the user accounts are configured as service accounts for applications. The applications send event notifications to the mailboxes of the service accounts by using SMTP. The developers of each application have delegated access to the mailbox of their respective application.
You need to ensure that all the event notifications sent by the applications are retained in the service account mailboxes so that new developers can review older notifications. The developers must be able to view only the notifications for their respective application. The solution must minimize licensing costs.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
Convert the "service account" mailboxes into shared mailboxes?
Or maybe convert "user mailbox" into shared one? OMG
C is correct

I guess the answer that makes the most sense is C. I don't think this is at all needed since delegation can be applied to a regular user mailbox, if not because of the requirement to "minimize licensing cost".

Selected Answer: C
The trick is in "You need to ensure that all the event notifications sent by the applications are retained in the service account mailboxes so that new developers can review older notifications." That the reason you need to convert the service account into a shared mailbox "...so that new developers can review older notifications"
on exam 11-27-21

Answer C is correct and reference is valid.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/email/convert-user-mailbox-to-shared-mailbox?view=o365-worldwide

choices.A: an Exchange ActiveSync device access rule
choices.B: an app protection policy in Microsoft Endpoint Manager
choices.C: an Outlook Web App policy in Exchange Online
choices.D: a device compliance policy in Microsoft Endpoint Manager

questions.question_text:
All the users in your company have Microsoft 365 mailboxes.
Each user connects to Microsoft Exchange Online and OneDrive for Business from a personal computer that runs Windows 10.
You need to ensure that the users can save attachments to OneDrive for Business only when they connect to their mailbox from Outlook on the web.
What should you create?

discussion.content: Wrong. Right answer should be C. an Outlook Web App policy in Exchange Online
C is wrong because it only defines if onedrive is allowed as storage for OWA or not, it won't restrict using onedrive in other apps like mobile outlook or desktop outlook. Right answer should be B.
C is correct

Selected Answer: B
block saving data from Outlook client onto OneDrive that way the requirement of being able to save to OneDrive

Selected Answer: C
the answer is C
https://m365scripts.com/exchange-online/restrict-external-storage-providers-in-owa/

get-OwaMailboxPolicy |fl id,*Attachments*,*fileaccess*

OneDriveAttachmentsEnabled : True
DirectFileAccessOnPublicComputersEnabled : False
DirectFileAccessOnPrivateComputersEnabled : False

Selected Answer: C
C is the most correct option

It is not possible with recent change in Endpoint manager to create an app protection policy for Windows devices (called WIP) for "without enrollment" type devices
That leaves us with C

Selected Answer: B
B. an app protection policy in Microsoft Endpoint Manager is the correct answer because this policy will allow you to configure settings that will ensure that attachments are saved to OneDrive for Business when users connect to their mailbox from Outlook on the web.

Selected Answer: C
In my opinion there is no correct answer to this question. Disabling Direct File access does not prevent the user from downloading the attachment. Also there is no option for OWA in Endpoint Manager.

If anyone has been able to do this via an app protection policy in Endpoint Manager or through an OWA Web App policy, please share with us how you did it.

This is the only valid method I could find, but it uses a conditional access policy in Azure combined with an OWA mailbox policy: https://profadmins.com/2021/10/09/restrict-downloading-attachments-from-owa/

Answer C is the least wrong.

Selected Answer: C
Right answer should be C.

Selected Answer: B
The App Protection Policy would block saving data from Outlook client on to OneDrive that way the requirement of being able to save to OneDrive ONLY when connected to Outlook web can be fulfilled.

comments.content: "You need to ensure that the users can save attachments [only] to OneDrive for Business when[ever] they connect to their mailbox from Outlook on the web." -- I think this is what most of the people in the comments are thinking? I mean... I'm happy to be corrected :)

discussion.content:
I'm not sure if the wording if this questions has been changed.

 "You need to ensure that the users can save attachments to OneDrive for Business only when they connect to their mailbox from Outlook on the web." --- My understanding is that saving attachments to OneDrive will only be available in OWA, not in Outlook client/mobile. 

I do not see this as an option in OWA Policies.. The best choice I think is B.

Right answer should be C
get-OwaMailboxPolicy |fl id,*Attachments*,*fileaccess*


Id : OwaMailboxPolicy-Default
OneDriveAttachmentsEnabled : True
ClassicAttachmentsEnabled : True
ReferenceAttachmentsEnabled : True
SaveAttachmentsToCloudEnabled : True
DirectFileAccessOnPublicComputersEnabled : False
DirectFileAccessOnPrivateComputersEnabled : False
Correct answer is C

Selected Answer: C
I tested it, with B it is not possible to block it

comments.content: Also, this is Not Intune test lol

discussion.content:
aaa.. found it. OwaMailboxPolicy-Default or Outlook Web App policy in EAC.
under File access - Direct file access(check box).

Enjoy!~

App protection policies allow to protect specific apps like Outlook for Android, Edge ... The question is about owa access which can be done through any supported browser. Owa policy allows to block direct file access and force attachment saving into onedrive...

https://www.vansurksum.com/2020/06/26/limit-access-to-outlook-web-access-and-sharepoint-online-and-onedrive-using-conditional-access-app-enforced-restrictions/
Look like C

comments.content: I totally agree with you. It does not say about the licensing part.

discussion.content:
I disabled direct file access for some users and confirm that it will only give users to save to OneDrive or view.
AFAIK, you need an Intune license to use app protection policies and among the Microsoft 365 licenses, only Business Premium includes that... The question does not specify the Microsoft 365 license of the users.
So I would say C

comments.content: Thank you for sharing, did it work for you? It did not in my lab. But Im quite sure app protection cannot be applied to web apps so there should be somewhere we can change on OWA policy.

Per the link by Cara 11
https://www.vansurksum.com/2020/06/26/limit-access-to-outlook-web-access-and-sharepoint-online-and-onedrive-using-conditional-access-app-enforced-restrictions/
"ReadOnly, where users can’t download attachments to their local computer, and can’t enable Offline Mode on non-compliant computers"...."can be accomplished by executing the following command: Set-OwaMailBoxPolicy -Identity OwaMailboxPolicy-Default -ConditionalAccessPolicy ReadOnly".. What's confusing to me is this setting doesnt appear in ECP. But if you run get-owamailboxpolicy in PS, you'll see most of the setting from ECPlisted(and alot more)..

discussion.content:
OWA Policy DOES NOT give you this .

Answer is correct.

Answer B seems correct - see below 
================================
App protection policies makes sure that the app-layer protections are in place. For example, you can:

Require a PIN to open an app in a work context
Control the sharing of data between apps
Prevent the saving of company app data to a personal storage location
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-policy

comments.content:
C is the answer. 
Answer B. App protection policies do not work like this for Windows devices that are not enrolled. These are personal Windows devices. Try it out and it's not an option
The answer needs to be C. Outlook Web App policy.
But they work n BYOD devices?

discussion.content:
I think C is the correct answer 
an Outlook Web App policy in Exchange Online
Reference: http://superhybridcloud.com/restricting-additional-storage-option-in-owa/
To restrict the third party storage accounts like Box or DropBox in OWA, disable that option by running the below command
Set-OWAMailboxPolicy “Policy Name” – AdditionalStorageProvidersAvailable:$false
Once that option disabled, user will not see the option to add third party storage option.
B, save to onedrive is on by defualt and we need to prevent user from use this functionality within outlook app, thas can be done via intune app protection policy
Answer:- C

C
https://www.pelegit.co.il/prevent-downloading-attachments-through-owa/
Physically tested on my tenant. It works.

This is the scenario where an app protection policy should be used
Ref:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-policy
C seems the right answer to me: OWA app policy can disable local saving, thus the user will only be able to save to OneDrive.

comments.content: OWA Policy has option to disable Direct File Access. If Direct File Access is Disable user will only have preview access to view a file. The only option available is to save the file to OneDrive.

After reading that i also think you are right. it clearly says :
Protecting your company data at the app level. Because mobile app management doesn't require device management,

I think B still OWA policy has no option for saving to one drive only. With app protection it covers the apps access by personal devices as well. See

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization.
You have the Address Book Policies (ABP) and address lists in the following table.
//IMG//

You have the users in the following table.
//IMG//

You assign ABP1 to User1 and User2.
User3 is NOT assigned to an Address Book Policy.
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Correct answers. 
Because: User 1 and User 2 in Not in the same GAL. BP1 has to have GAL with both Users in it to see each other. 
User 3 is not part of BP 1, so he can see entire Org by default.
With Love~

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/address-books/address-book-policies/assign-an-address-book-policy-to-mail-users. 

"
Users aren't automatically assigned an ABP when you create mailboxes. If you don't assign an ABP to a mailbox, the GAL for your entire organization is visible to the user in Outlook and Outlook on the web. Furthermore, a user that's assigned an ABP needs to exist in the GAL that's specified for the ABP. For more information, see Considerations and best practices for address book policies."
Is correct

Agree with the answers:

User 1 and User 2 are not in the same GAL. So, logically they cannot see each other.
User 3 is not part of ABP 1, so he can see entire Org by default (default GAL).

comments.content: User2 in ABP1... be careful word
user2 already added to GAL1

"A user that's assigned an ABP needs to exist in the GAL that's specified for the ABP."
- In this case, it is safe to assume that User2 was added to GAL1, and then assigned ABP1 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/address-books/address-book-policies/assign-an-address-book-policy-to-mail-users

A compliance manager plans to create retention policies for the mailboxes of executive users. The policies will move specific emails to an archive mailbox.
You need to create an archive mailbox for each executive user.
What should you do?

You can't use set-mailbox to create an archive, it's enable-mailbox %user% -archive
